title: Noise from guns is a public safety issue
text:
Noise from guns is a public safety issue Feb 5, 2017 ( … ) 
Kevin Horrigan's "Sounds of silencers" (Jan. 29) is one of the most misleading columns I've seen in years. Guns are very loud, and are a principal reason in my mid-50s I have significant hearing loss, in particular at higher frequencies. So yes indeed, it's a public health issue. 
Suppressors weren't effectively legislated out of the common man's hands to "deter gangland-style weapons." The government's stated reason was to reduce poaching during the Great Depression, and that attempt failed miserably. 
Horrigan forgets to mention that suppressed pistols are more than doubled in length, much more difficult to conceal and essentially impossible to holster, making their use by criminals unlikely. He misleadingly explains that a reduction of 162 to 138 decibels is still "dangerous," but decibel reduction isn't linear, it's logarithmic. So the noise reduction is huge at firing ranges. 
Most suppressors will be purchased for .22-caliber long rifles, including those used to introduce youths, including Boy Scouts and Girl Scouts, to shooting. Isn't public safety invariably about the safety of the children? 
David Armbruster • Ferguson
